intro: Brassica corsica, commonly known as the Corsican mustard, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes other well-known species like cabbage and mustard. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its leaves are alternate, lobed, and often have a distinct mustardy aroma. Brassica corsica is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of habitats, including roadsides and dry grasslands.
